I think the original commenter meant, "it makes it harder for real victims". This rings true for anyone who's ever known, or been, a real victim of abuse that was not believed, where a case was even brought forth but the authorities ultimately decided "he/she was probably making it up" and their abuser gets off scot-free. That happens a lot more often than most people think, even in our "post-MeToo" world. That being said, Where is the precedent for someone "probably making it up" set? Women like Amber Heard. _Real_ cases get dismissed because a judge or jury know every alleged victim _could_ be another Amber Heard.

I imagine this sentiment will only increase in society at large when Hollywood utterly destroys the credibility of _all_ female victims of abuse -- the real ones, I mean. Which is disgusting, considering that Hollywood will have been the cause of it.

People really do need a reality check on exactly how these people live - they are all degrees of bad and seldom go out of their way to be nice without some kind of compensation or otherwise something in it for them.

Most actors that do good PR events like visiting hospitals and such do so for PR's sake and boosting their image, if not for the film production studio they commonly work with - as I have zero doubt all MCU actors that do so such things, it just plays well for everyone especially family conscious film companies like Disney.

Even Michael J Fox - despite all his philanthropy towards Parkinsons/dementia research organisations he does little else and has plenty of money to do so.

The average AAA pay grade actor gets more pay from a single film job and its associated PR events than the average lower level film crew member will make in their entire lifetime.

Let me make that clear in case you didn't quite read it right - THEIR ENTIRE LIFETIME.

That especially includes all the VFX studio people that work unpaid overtime constantly to get all of that work done that the actors never even touch yet covers for so much of the average AAA film these days.

My main point being that not a single actor in Hollywood needs your pity - they know that it is a cesspool, they do it anyways, and they and the higher level film crew are the only people involved in any production that actually gets well paid for it by Hollywood standards.

It's the rest of the crew that really deserve your pity - they do all the work, get all the shit, receive a piss poor wage compensation and none of the PR recognition from the studios, as far as the studios are concerned they are practically production props that get paid.
